docs.title: TFGrid Studio Documentation
docs.text:
Complete development platform for ThreeFold Grid

Build, deploy, and scale decentralized applications with tfgrid-compose CLI and integrated tools.

🌐 New here? Check out our main website for an overview of TFGrid Studio, pricing, and features.

docs.title: 🎯 What is TFGrid Studio?
docs.text:
TFGrid Studio is a complete development platform for ThreeFold Grid. The flagship tool, tfgrid-compose, brings docker-compose-style simplicity to decentralized deployments.

# Deploy any application with one command
tfgrid-compose up my-app

No vendor lock-in. Industry standards. Decentralized infrastructure.

docs.title: 1. Install tfgrid-compose
docs.text:
# One-line installer
curl -sSL install.tfgrid.studio/install.sh | sh

# Verify installation
tfgrid-compose --version

docs.title: 2. Set Up ThreeFold
docs.text:
Need a ThreeFold wallet with TFT? See the complete setup guide.

Already have a wallet? Configure it: 

tfgrid-compose login
# Enter your seed phrase when prompted

docs.title: 3. Deploy an App
docs.text:
# Deploy official app (v0.10.0+)
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent

# Or use local path (current)
tfgrid-compose up ../tfgrid-ai-agent

# Or specify app path
tfgrid-compose up ../tfgrid-ai-agent

That's it! Your application is now running on ThreeFold Grid. 🎉

docs.title: 🎯 Use Cases
docs.text:
Deploy isolated AI coding environments on ThreeFold Grid. 

tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent

docs.title: Web Applications
docs.text:
Deploy web apps with public IPv4, SSL, and reverse proxy. 

tfgrid-compose up my-webapp --pattern=gateway --domain=myapp.com

docs.title: Cloud-Native Apps
docs.text:
Deploy microservices on Kubernetes clusters.

docs.title: Databases

Deploy databases with persistent storage and private networking.

docs.title: TFGrid Compose Architecture
docs.text: Version: 0.9.0 Status: Active Audience: Developers, Contributors, Advanced Users

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text:
1. System Overview
  2. Core Components
  3. Data Flow
  4. Pattern System
  5. State Management
  6. Extension Guide
  7. Design Decisions
  8. Performance Considerations

docs.title: Design Philosophy
docs.text:
1. Pattern-Based Architecture

  • Patterns encapsulate infrastructure, platform, and application concerns
  • Orchestrator is pattern-agnostic (knows nothing about pattern internals)
  • New patterns can be added without modifying core code

2. Contract-Driven Integration

  • Patterns must implement a standard contract
  • Orchestrator consumes contract outputs (primary_ip, deployment_name, etc.)
  • Loose coupling enables extensibility

3. Shell-Based Implementation

  • Bash scripts for simplicity and transparency
  • Easy to understand, debug, and extend
  • Minimal dependencies (bash, common Unix tools)
  • Works on any Unix-like system (Linux, macOS)

docs.title: 1. CLI Entry Point (cli/tfgrid-compose)
docs.text:
Purpose: User-facing command interface

Responsibilities:

  • Parse command-line arguments
  • Load context file (.tfgrid-compose.yaml)
  • Route commands to appropriate handlers
  • Display help and version information

Key Features:

  • Context file support for simplified commands
  • Command aliases (e.g., agent subcommand)
  • Global flags (--debug, --version)

Example Flow: 

tfgrid-compose up /path/to/app
    ↓
Load context (optional)
    ↓
Validate prerequisites
    ↓
Call orchestrator.deploy_app()

docs.title: 2. Common Utilities (core/common.sh)
docs.text:
Purpose: Shared functions used across all modules

Key Functions:

# Logging
log_info()      # Informational messages
log_success()   # Success indicators
log_warning()   # Warnings
log_error()     # Errors
log_step()      # Major steps

# Utilities
command_exists()    # Check if command is available
yaml_get()          # Extract values from YAML files
state_save()        # Save to state file
state_get()         # Retrieve from state file
state_clear()       # Clear state directory

Color-Coded Output:

  • 🔵 Blue: Informational
  • ✅ Green: Success
  • ⚠️ Yellow: Warnings
  • ❌ Red: Errors
  • ▶ Purple: Major steps

docs.title: 3. Validation Module (core/validation.sh)
docs.text:
Purpose: Validate prerequisites and configurations

Validation Stages:

validate_prerequisites()
    ├── Check OpenTofu/Terraform (prefer OpenTofu)
    ├── Check Ansible
    ├── Check SSH client
    ├── Check WireGuard (optional warning)
    ├── Load ThreeFold mnemonic
    └── Export TF_CMD environment variable

validate_app_path()
    ├── Check directory exists
    └── Check tfgrid-compose.yaml exists

validate_deployment_exists()
    ├── Check .tfgrid-compose/ directory
    └── Check state.yaml file

validate_no_deployment()
    └── Prevent duplicate deployments

validate_network_prerequisites()
    ├── Check WireGuard (if needed)
    ├── Check Mycelium (if needed)
    └── Test connectivity

Mnemonic Loading Priority: 1. Environment variable: $TF_VAR_mnemonic 2. Standard location: ~/.config/threefold/mnemonic 3. Project-specific: ./.tfgrid-mnemonic

OpenTofu Priority: 

# Check tofu first (open source)
if command -v tofu; then
    export TF_CMD="tofu"
elif command -v terraform; then
    export TF_CMD="terraform"
else
    error "Neither found"
fi

docs.title: 4. Pattern Loader (core/pattern-loader.sh)
docs.text:
Purpose: Load and validate deployment patterns

Pattern Structure: 

patterns/
└── single-vm/
    ├── pattern.yaml           # Pattern metadata
    ├── infrastructure/        # Terraform/OpenTofu files
    │   ├── main.tf
    │   ├── variables.tf
    │   └── outputs.tf        # MUST implement contract
    ├── platform/             # Ansible playbooks
    │   ├── site.yml
    │   └── roles/
    └── README.md

Pattern Loading Flow: 

load_pattern()
    ├── Read pattern name from app manifest
    ├── Validate pattern directory exists
    ├── Load pattern.yaml metadata
    ├── Verify infrastructure/ (Terraform files)
    ├── Verify platform/ (Ansible playbooks)
    └── Export pattern variables

Pattern Metadata (pattern.yaml): 

name: single-vm
version: 1.0.0
description: Single VM deployment
requires:
  - terraform  # or opentofu
  - ansible
  - wireguard  # optional

docs.title: 5. App Loader (core/app-loader.sh)
docs.text:
Purpose: Load and validate application manifests

App Manifest (tfgrid-compose.yaml): 

name: my-app
version: 1.0.0
pattern: single-vm

# Pattern configuration
config:
  node: 8
  cpu: 4
  memory: 8192
  disk: 102400

# Optional app-specific hooks
hooks:
  setup: ./deployment/hooks/setup.sh
  configure: ./deployment/hooks/configure.sh
  healthcheck: ./deployment/hooks/healthcheck.sh

App Loading Flow: 

load_app()
    ├── Parse tfgrid-compose.yaml
    ├── Extract app metadata
    ├── Load pattern configuration
    ├── Validate hooks (if present)
    └── Export app variables

docs.title: 6. Orchestrator (core/orchestrator.sh)
docs.text:
Purpose: Main deployment orchestration logic

Deployment Flow:

deploy_app()
    │
    ├─ 1. VALIDATION PHASE
    │      ├── Validate system prerequisites
    │      ├── Validate no existing deployment
    │      ├── Validate app path and manifest
    │      └── Load pattern and app config
    │
    ├─ 2. INFRASTRUCTURE PHASE
    │      ├── Generate Terraform config
    │      ├── Run: terraform init
    │      ├── Run: terraform plan
    │      ├── Run: terraform apply
    │      └── Extract outputs (primary_ip, node_ids, etc.)
    │
    ├─ 3. NETWORK PHASE
    │      ├── If primary_ip_type == "wireguard":
    │      │    ├── Extract WireGuard config
    │      │    ├── Deploy to /etc/wireguard/
    │      │    └── Start wg-quick up
    │      └── Test connectivity
    │
    ├─ 4. WAIT PHASE
    │      ├── Wait for SSH (up to 5 minutes)
    │      ├── Retry connection every 10 seconds
    │      └── Verify SSH access
    │
    ├─ 5. PLATFORM PHASE
    │      ├── Generate Ansible inventory
    │      ├── Run: ansible-playbook site.yml
    │      └── Configure base system
    │
    ├─ 6. APPLICATION PHASE
    │      ├── Copy app source to VM
    │      ├── Run setup hook (if present)
    │      ├── Run configure hook (if present)
    │      └── Run healthcheck hook (if present)
    │
    ├─ 7. VERIFICATION PHASE
    │      ├── Test SSH connectivity
    │      ├── Check application service
    │      └── Validate deployment
    │
    └─ 8. FINALIZATION
           ├── Save deployment metadata
           ├── Display connection info
           └── Show next steps

Destroy Flow: 

destroy_deployment()
    ├── Validate deployment exists
    ├── Stop WireGuard interface (if active)
    ├── Run: terraform destroy
    └── Clear state directory

docs.title: 7. Task Executors (core/tasks/)
docs.text: Purpose: Execute specific deployment tasks

docs.title: terraform.sh
docs.text:
# Detects OpenTofu or Terraform
TF_CMD detection (tofu → terraform → error)
    ├── terraform init
    ├── terraform plan
    ├── terraform apply
    └── Extract outputs to state.yaml

docs.title: wireguard.sh
docs.text:
# Sets up WireGuard VPN
    ├── Extract wg_config from Terraform
    ├── Generate interface name (wg0, wg1, ...)
    ├── Deploy to /etc/wireguard/
    ├── Handle conflicts with existing interfaces
    └── Start interface with wg-quick

docs.title: ansible.sh
docs.text:
# Configures platform
    ├── Generate inventory from state
    ├── Test connectivity
    ├── Run playbook
    └── Capture logs

docs.title: wait-ssh.sh
docs.text:
# Waits for SSH to be ready
    ├── Timeout: 300 seconds (5 minutes)
    ├── Retry: Every 10 seconds
    ├── Test: ssh -o BatchMode=yes <ip> 'echo ok'
    └── Early exit on first success

docs.title: State Directory Structure
docs.text:
.tfgrid-compose/
├── state.yaml                    # Deployment metadata
├── terraform/                    # Generated Terraform config
│   ├── main.tf
│   ├── variables.tf
│   ├── outputs.tf
│   ├── .terraform/              # Terraform state
│   └── terraform.tfstate
├── inventory.ini                 # Generated Ansible inventory
├── wg0.conf                     # WireGuard config (if used)
├── terraform-init.log           # Terraform init log
├── terraform-plan.log           # Terraform plan log
├── terraform-apply.log          # Terraform apply log
├── ansible.log                  # Ansible playbook log
├── hook-setup.log              # Setup hook log
├── hook-configure.log          # Configure hook log
└── hook-healthcheck.log        # Healthcheck hook log

docs.title: State File (state.yaml)
docs.text:
# Metadata
app_name: my-app
app_version: 1.0.0

deployment_id: abc123xyz

# Infrastructure outputs

docs.title: Pattern Contract
docs.text:
Every pattern MUST implement the standard contract.

Required Terraform Outputs: 

output "primary_ip" {
  value = "10.1.3.2"
  description = "Primary IP for SSH"
}

output "primary_ip_type" {
  value = "wireguard"  # or "public" or "mycelium"
  description = "Type of primary IP"
}

output "deployment_name" {
  value = "vm_abc123"
  description = "Deployment name"
}

output "node_ids" {
  value = [8]
  description = "Node IDs used"
}

docs.title: 1. Single-VM Pattern
docs.text:
Use Case: Development, databases, internal services, AI agents

Infrastructure:

  • 1 VM on TFGrid
  • WireGuard private network
  • Optional Mycelium IPv6

Network:

  • Primary: WireGuard IP (10.x.x.x)
  • Secondary: Mycelium IP (IPv6)

Platform:

  • Ubuntu 24.04
  • Base packages (git, curl, build-essential)
  • Docker (optional)

docs.title: 2. Gateway Pattern
docs.text:
Use Case: Production web apps with public IPv4

Infrastructure:

  • 1 Gateway VM (public IPv4)
  • N Backend VMs (private network)
  • WireGuard + Mycelium

Network:

  • Primary: Public IPv4 (gateway)
  • Secondary: WireGuard IPs (backends)

Platform:

  • Gateway: Nginx/HAProxy reverse proxy
  • Backends: Application servers
  • SSL/TLS: Let's Encrypt (automated)

docs.title: 3. K3s Pattern
docs.text:
Use Case: Kubernetes clusters

Infrastructure:

  • 1+ Control plane nodes
  • N Worker nodes
  • 1 Management node (kubectl, helm, k9s)

Network:

  • Primary: Control plane WireGuard IP
  • Secondary: Worker node IPs

Platform:

  • K3s lightweight Kubernetes
  • MetalLB load balancer
  • Nginx Ingress Controller
  • Local-path storage provisioner

docs.title: State Lifecycle
docs.text:
┌──────────────┐
│   No State   │  Initial state
└──────┬───────┘
       │
       │  deploy_app()
       ▼
┌──────────────┐
│  Deploying   │  Terraform running
└──────┬───────┘
       │
       │  Success
       ▼
┌──────────────┐
│   Running    │  Deployment active
└──────┬───────┘
       │
       │  destroy_deployment()
       ▼
┌──────────────┐
│  Destroying  │  Terraform destroy
└──────┬───────┘
       │
       │  Success
       ▼
┌──────────────┐
│   Cleaned    │  State removed
└──────────────┘

docs.title: State Operations
docs.text:
Create State: 

create_state_dir()
    mkdir -p .tfgrid-compose
    touch .tfgrid-compose/state.yaml

Save to State: 

state_save "key" "value"
    echo "key: value" >> .tfgrid-compose/state.yaml

Read from State: 

state_get "key"
    grep "^key:" .tfgrid-compose/state.yaml | awk '{print $2}'

Clear State: 

state_clear()
    rm -rf .tfgrid-compose/

docs.title: State Validation
docs.text:
Check Deployment Exists: 

if [ -f ".tfgrid-compose/state.yaml" ]; then
    echo "Deployment exists"
fi

Prevent Duplicate Deployments: 

validate_no_deployment()
    if deployment_exists; then
        show current deployment info
        error "Cannot deploy while another exists"
    fi

docs.title: Adding a New Pattern
docs.text:
1. Create Pattern Directory: 

patterns/my-pattern/
├── pattern.yaml
├── infrastructure/
│   └── main.tf         # Implement pattern contract!
├── platform/
│   └── site.yml
└── README.md

2. Implement Pattern Contract: 

# infrastructure/outputs.tf
output "primary_ip" {
  value = your_resource.primary_ip
}

output "primary_ip_type" {
  value = "wireguard"
}

output "deployment_name" {
  value = your_resource.name
}

output "node_ids" {
  value = [var.node_id]
}

3. Test Pattern: 

# Test with example app
tfgrid-compose up /path/to/test-app

# Verify outputs
cd .tfgrid-compose/terraform
terraform output primary_ip
terraform output primary_ip_type

4. Document Pattern: 

# My Pattern

## Use Cases

- What problems does this solve?

## Configuration

- What options are available?

## Example

- Show complete example

docs.title: Adding a New Task
docs.text:
1. Create Task Script: 

core/tasks/my-task.sh

2. Implement Task: 

#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -e

SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
source "$SCRIPT_DIR/../common.sh"

log_step "Running my task..."

# Task implementation
# ...

log_success "Task complete"

3. Call from Orchestrator: 

# In core/orchestrator.sh
if ! bash "$DEPLOYER_ROOT/core/tasks/my-task.sh"; then
    log_error "My task failed"
    return 1
fi

docs.title: Adding New Commands
docs.text:
1. Add Command Handler: 

# In cli/tfgrid-compose
case "$COMMAND" in
    my-command)
        # Implementation
        ;;
esac

2. Update Help Text: 

# In core/common.sh show_help()
echo "  my-command <args>  - Description"

docs.title: Why Bash?
docs.text:
Pros:

  • ✅ Universal availability (every Unix system)
  • ✅ Easy to understand and debug
  • ✅ Transparent execution (no compilation)
  • ✅ Excellent for orchestration
  • ✅ Direct integration with CLI tools
  • ✅ Minimal dependencies

Cons:

  • ❌ Error handling can be tricky
  • ❌ No type safety
  • ❌ Testing is harder

Mitigation:

  • Use set -e (exit on error)
  • Extensive validation
  • Logging at each step
  • Test scripts provided

docs.title: Why Pattern-Based?
docs.text:
Benefits:

  • Different use cases need different infrastructure
  • Patterns encapsulate best practices
  • Easy to add new patterns without modifying core
  • Users can create custom patterns

Alternatives Considered:

  • Single monolithic template (too rigid)
  • Full config DSL (too complex)
  • GUI builder (not CLI-friendly)

docs.title: Why OpenTofu Priority?
docs.text:
Rationale:

  • Open source (Apache 2.0 license)
  • Compatible with Terraform
  • Community-driven development
  • No license restrictions
  • Same user experience

Fallback:

  • Terraform still supported
  • Auto-detection at runtime
  • No breaking changes

docs.title: Why State in .tfgrid-compose/?
docs.text:
Benefits:

  • Co-located with deployment
  • Easy to find and inspect
  • Git-ignored by default
  • Self-contained

Alternatives:

  • ~/.tfgrid/ (harder to track per-project)
  • Database (added complexity)
  • Cloud storage (requires connectivity)

docs.title: Deployment Speed
docs.text:
Typical Timeline:

  • Infrastructure (Terraform): 30-60 seconds
  • Network setup (WireGuard): 5-10 seconds
  • Wait for SSH: 30-90 seconds
  • Platform config (Ansible): 60-120 seconds
  • App deployment: 10-30 seconds

Total: 2-5 minutes

docs.title: Optimization Opportunities
docs.text:
1. Parallel Execution:

  • Multiple Ansible hosts configured in parallel
  • Background tasks where possible

2. Caching:

  • Terraform state cached locally
  • Ansible facts cached between runs

3. Incremental Updates:

  • Only run changed playbooks
  • Terraform plan before apply

docs.title: Resource Usage
docs.text:
Local Machine:

  • Minimal CPU usage (mostly waiting)
  • Small disk footprint (<50MB for state)
  • Network: Depends on Terraform operations

Remote VMs:

  • Configured per pattern requirements
  • Single-VM: 2-8 CPU, 4-16GB RAM typical
  • Gateway: 1-2 CPU per VM, 2-4GB RAM
  • K3s: 2+ CPU per node, 4+GB RAM

docs.title: Mnemonic Security
docs.text:
Storage:

  • File permissions: 600 (read/write owner only)
  • Standard location: ~/.config/threefold/mnemonic
  • Warning if permissions are incorrect

Best Practices:

  • Never commit to version control
  • Use environment variable in CI/CD
  • Rotate regularly

docs.title: SSH Key Management
docs.text:
Default Behavior:

  • Uses system SSH keys (~/.ssh/id_*.pub)
  • Injected into VMs during deployment
  • No passwords (key-based auth only)

docs.title: WireGuard Security
docs.text:
Private Keys:

  • Generated by Terraform provider
  • Stored in Terraform state (encrypted at rest)
  • Deployed to /etc/wireguard/ with 600 permissions

Network Isolation:

  • Private networks per deployment
  • No default internet routing
  • Explicit rules required for external access

docs.title: Debug Mode
docs.text:
Enable: 

tfgrid-compose --debug up <app>

Effects:

  • Verbose logging (set -x)
  • Keep temporary files
  • Show all command output
  • Network diagnostics

docs.title: Log Files
docs.text:
All logs saved to .tfgrid-compose/:

  • terraform-init.log
  • terraform-plan.log
  • terraform-apply.log
  • ansible.log
  • hook-*.log

docs.title: State Inspection
docs.text:
Check Deployment: 

cat .tfgrid-compose/state.yaml

Check Terraform State: 

cd .tfgrid-compose/terraform
terraform show

Check WireGuard: 

sudo wg show

docs.title: Planned Enhancements
docs.text:
1. Multi-Deployment Support 

~/.tfgrid-compose/
├── deployments/
│   ├── abc123/  # Deployment 1
│   └── def456/  # Deployment 2
└── index.yaml   # Registry

    bucket: my-tfgrid-state

docs.title: TFGrid Studio Platform Map
docs.text:
High-level overview of how TFGrid Studio components, repositories, and websites fit together.

This page complements the low-level Architecture docs by giving a product-level map of:

  • Core CLI and patterns
  • Official apps (AI Agent, AI Stack, Gitea)
  • Registry and install flows
  • Documentation and marketing sites
  • Dashboards (local vs planned hosted)

docs.title: 1. High-Level Picture
docs.text:
Developer / User
   │
   ├─ CLI: tfgrid-compose  ("t")
   │    ├─ Patterns: single-vm, gateway, k3s
   │    └─ Apps: tfgrid-ai-agent, tfgrid-ai-stack, tfgrid-gitea, community apps
   │
   ├─ Local Dashboard: tfgrid-compose dashboard
   │    └─ Visual wrapper over the same CLI + registry + state
   │
   ├─ Documentation: docs.tfgrid.studio
   │
   └─ Web Properties:
        - tfgrid.studio            (marketing)
        - install.tfgrid.studio    (installer)
        - registry.tfgrid.studio   (app catalogue)

At the center is tfgrid-compose, which knows how to:

  • Read app manifests (tfgrid-compose.yaml)
  • Apply patterns (single-vm, gateway, k3s)
  • Deploy and manage apps on ThreeFold Grid

Everything else (apps, registry, dashboard, docs, websites) is built on top of this core.

docs.title: 2.1 tfgrid-compose CLI
docs.text:
• Repository: tfgrid-compose
  • Role: universal deployer/orchestrator for ThreeFold Grid.
  • Responsibilities:
  • Parse commands (up, down, status, logs, ssh, exec, create, run, publish, etc.).
  • Load context files (.tfgrid-compose.yaml).
  • Orchestrate Terraform/OpenTofu, WireGuard/Mycelium, Ansible, and app hooks.
  • Maintain state in .tfgrid-compose/ and deployments.yaml.

Shortcuts:

  • Default shortcut tfgrid is created at install time.
  • Users can create their own, for example t, via tfgrid-compose shortcut t.

docs.title: 2.2 Patterns
docs.text:
Patterns live inside tfgrid-compose/patterns/ and define infrastructure + platform for apps:

  • single-vm
  • One VM on the grid.
  • WireGuard + optional Mycelium networking.

  • Used by: tfgrid-ai-agent, tfgrid-ai-stack, tfgrid-gitea, and many future apps.

  • gateway

  • Public IPv4 gateway VM + private backend VMs.
  • Nginx/HAProxy, SSL (Let[200~'s Encrypt), path-based routing.

  • Ideal for production web apps.

  • k3s

  • K3s Kubernetes clusters with control plane, workers, and management node.
  • MetalLB, Ingress, storage, etc.

Low-level details of these patterns live in Architecture → System Architecture and pattern-specific docs.

docs.title: 3. Official Apps on Top of the Patterns
3.1 TFGrid AI Agent
docs.text:

docs.title: 3.2 TFGrid AI Stack
docs.text:

  • Pattern: single-vm (stacked services on one VM).
  • Components:
  • Nginx reverse proxy (/, /git/, /api/).

  • Gitea Git server (/git/).
  • Key CLI flows:
  • tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-stack – deploy full AI + Git + gateway stack.
  • tfgrid-compose create – create AI-generated projects.
  • tfgrid-compose run / monitor – run and observe AI loops.
  • tfgrid-compose publish – expose projects as websites.

URL model after publish:

  • Git: http://<ip-or-mycelium>/git/<org>/<project>
  • Web: http://<ip-or-mycelium>/web/<org>/<project>

Where <ip-or-mycelium> can be a WireGuard IP (e.g. 10.1.3.2) or a Mycelium address.

docs.title: App-Specific Commands
docs.text: How apps define custom commands and how to use them.

docs.title: Design Philosophy
docs.text:
Universal CLI, App-Specific Features

tfgrid-compose provides a universal interface where:

  • 🔧 Generic commands work for all apps (up, down, status, logs, ssh)
  • 🎯 App-specific commands are defined by each app (create, run, stop, etc.)
  • 🚀 One CLI to rule them all

Each app becomes a first-class citizen with its own command set!

docs.title: 1. Apps Define Commands in Manifest
docs.text:
Apps declare their commands in tfgrid-compose.yaml:

name: tfgrid-ai-agent
version: 0.3.0
description: AI-powered coding agent

# App-specific commands
commands:
  create:
    script: /opt/ai-agent/scripts/create-project.sh
    description: Create a new AI coding project
    args: "[project-name]"

  run:
    script: /opt/ai-agent/scripts/run-project.sh
    description: Start agent loop for a project
    args: "[project-name]"

  projects:
    script: /opt/ai-agent/scripts/status-projects.sh
    description: Show status of all projects

docs.title: 2. tfgrid-compose Routes Commands
docs.text:
When you run a command:

tfgrid-compose create my-project

tfgrid-compose:

  1. ✅ Checks if it's a generic command
  2. ✅ If not, looks in active app's manifest
  3. ✅ Finds the script path
  4. ✅ Executes on the VM via SSH

You get native app functionality through the universal CLI!

docs.title: Generic Commands
docs.text:
These work for all apps:

Command Description up Deploy app to ThreeFold Grid down Destroy deployment status Check app status logs View app logs ssh Connect to VM exec Execute arbitrary command list List deployed apps switch Change active app config Manage configuration settings

Universal operations - Every app supports these.

docs.title: tfgrid-ai-agent Commands
docs.text:
The AI coding agent provides these commands:

# Project Management
tfgrid-compose create [project-name]     # Create new AI project
tfgrid-compose run [project-name]        # Start agent loop
tfgrid-compose stop [project-name]       # Stop agent loop
tfgrid-compose remove [project-name]     # Delete project

# Monitoring
tfgrid-compose projects                  # Show all projects
tfgrid-compose monitor [project-name]    # Watch progress
tfgrid-compose logs [project-name]       # View project logs
tfgrid-compose summary [project-name]    # Show summary

# Operations
tfgrid-compose edit [project-name]       # Edit configuration
tfgrid-compose restart [project-name]    # Restart agent
tfgrid-compose stopall                   # Stop all projects

# Setup
tfgrid-compose login                     # Configure git credentials
tfgrid-compose version                   # Show agent version

docs.title: Future Apps
docs.text:
Other apps will define their own commands:

Example: web-dashboard 

tfgrid-compose deploy      # Deploy dashboard
tfgrid-compose config      # Configure settings
tfgrid-compose backup      # Backup data

Example: api-backend 

tfgrid-compose migrate     # Run migrations
tfgrid-compose seed        # Seed database
tfgrid-compose scale N     # Scale to N instances

Each app = Custom command set!

docs.title: See Available Commands
docs.text:
# Generic help
tfgrid-compose help

# App-specific: Try a command
tfgrid-compose create
# → If not recognized, shows: "Unknown command: create"
# → Lists available app commands

docs.title: Read App Manifest
docs.text:
# View app's commands
cat ~/.config/tfgrid-compose/apps/tfgrid-ai-agent/tfgrid-compose.yaml

# Look for 'commands:' section

docs.title: Pattern 1: Interactive Projects (AI Agent)
docs.text:
# Create project (interactive prompts)
tfgrid-compose create music-website
  → Prompts for duration, template, etc.

# Start the agent
tfgrid-compose run music-website
  → Agent loop begins coding

# Monitor progress
tfgrid-compose monitor music-website
  → Watch in real-time

# Check results
tfgrid-compose summary music-website
  → See what was accomplished

docs.title: Pattern 2: Service Management (Web Apps)
docs.text:
# Deploy service
tfgrid-compose deploy

# Check status
tfgrid-compose status

# Update configuration (use config set instead)
tfgrid-compose config set key value

# Restart
tfgrid-compose restart

docs.title: Pattern 3: Data Operations (Databases)
docs.text:
# Run migrations
tfgrid-compose migrate

# Backup data
tfgrid-compose backup production

# Restore data
tfgrid-compose restore backup-2024.tar.gz

Each app defines its own patterns!

docs.title: Optional Arguments
docs.text:
Many commands take optional project/resource names:

# Interactive selection (if no name given)
tfgrid-compose run
  → Shows list, pick one

# Direct specification
tfgrid-compose run my-project
  → Runs immediately

docs.title: Positional vs Flags
docs.text:
# Positional (simple)
tfgrid-compose create my-project

# With flags (advanced)
tfgrid-compose create my-project --template=web --duration=2h

Apps decide their own syntax!

docs.title: For App Developers
docs.text:
1. Write the script:

#!/bin/bash
# /opt/myapp/scripts/my-command.sh

echo "Executing custom command..."
# Your logic here

2. Add to manifest:

commands:
  my-command:
    script: /opt/myapp/scripts/my-command.sh
    description: Do something awesome
    args: "[optional-arg]"

3. Deploy:

tfgrid-compose up myapp

4. Use:

tfgrid-compose my-command

That's it! Your app now has custom commands.

docs.title: Design Your Commands
docs.text:
✅ DO: - Use clear, action-oriented names (create, deploy, backup) - Make commands idempotent when possible - Provide helpful error messages - Support both interactive and non-interactive modes

❌ DON'T: - Use generic names that conflict (status, logs are reserved) - Require complex flag combinations - Make breaking changes without version bump

docs.title: Command Naming
docs.text:
# Good (clear actions)
create, run, stop, deploy, backup, migrate

# Avoid (ambiguous)
do-stuff, process, handle, manage

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
# Good (optional, with selection)
tfgrid-compose run [project-name]
  → Interactive if omitted

# Good (clear meaning)
tfgrid-compose backup --output=/path/to/backup.tar.gz

# Avoid (too many required args)
tfgrid-compose complex command arg1 arg2 arg3 arg4

docs.title: Command Resolution
docs.text:
User runs: tfgrid-compose create my-project

1. Parse command line
   → Command: "create"
   → Args: ["my-project"]

2. Check generic commands
   → Not found

3. Get active context
   → App: tfgrid-ai-agent

4. Load app manifest
   → commands.create.script: /opt/ai-agent/scripts/create-project.sh

5. Execute on VM
   → ssh root@10.1.3.2 "/opt/ai-agent/scripts/create-project.sh my-project"

docs.title: Script Execution
docs.text:
Commands run with:

  • SSH TTY - Interactive prompts work
  • Arguments passed - Via command line
  • Exit codes - Propagated to local CLI

docs.title: Example 1: AI Agent Workflow
docs.text:
# Configure credentials (one time)
tfgrid-compose login

# Create projects
tfgrid-compose create website-redesign
tfgrid-compose create api-refactor
tfgrid-compose create docs-update

# Start agents
tfgrid-compose run website-redesign

# Check status
tfgrid-compose projects

# Monitor specific project

# View results
tfgrid-compose summary website-redesign
tfgrid-compose logs website-redesign

docs.title: Example 2: Multi-App Deployment
docs.text:
# Deploy multiple apps
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent
tfgrid-compose up web-dashboard
tfgrid-compose up api-backend

# Switch context for different tasks
tfgrid-compose switch tfgrid-ai-agent
tfgrid-compose create backend-rewrite

tfgrid-compose switch api-backend
tfgrid-compose migrate

tfgrid-compose switch web-dashboard
tfgrid-compose deploy

docs.title: Context System
docs.text: Learn how tfgrid-compose's context system makes managing multiple apps seamless.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The context system allows you to work with multiple deployed apps without constantly specifying which one you're targeting. It's like setting a "current directory" for your deployed apps.

Key Features: - 🎯 Smart auto-detection - Single app? No setup needed! - 🔄 Select between apps - tfgrid-compose select - 🔄 Select between projects - tfgrid-compose select-project (for apps that support it) - 📝 Context-aware commands - Commands use active app and project - 🌐 Both modes - Explicit or contextual

docs.title: 1. Smart Context Detection
docs.text:
When you have exactly one app deployed, tfgrid-compose automatically uses it:

# Deploy first app
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent

# These just work! No switch needed
tfgrid-compose create my-project
tfgrid-compose projects
tfgrid-compose logs my-project

✅ No configuration required

docs.title: 2. Multiple Apps - Explicit Context
docs.text:
With multiple apps, you need to set context:

# Deploy second app
tfgrid-compose up some-web-app

# Now you need to specify which app
tfgrid-compose select tfgrid-ai-agent

# Commands now target tfgrid-ai-agent
tfgrid-compose create my-project

docs.title: 3. Check Current Context
docs.text:
# List all deployed apps
tfgrid-compose list

# Output:
#   * tfgrid-ai-agent (active) - 10.1.3.2
#     some-web-app - 10.1.3.5
#
# ℹ Active context: tfgrid-ai-agent

docs.title: select - Change Active App
docs.text:
Set which app commands should target:

# Select an app
tfgrid-compose select tfgrid-ai-agent

# All subsequent commands use this app
tfgrid-compose create project1
tfgrid-compose run project1

When to use: - You have multiple apps deployed - You want to work with a specific app for a while

docs.title: unselect - Clear Active App
docs.text:
Clear the current app selection:

# Clear app context
tfgrid-compose unselect

# Commands now require explicit app
tfgrid-compose create project  # Error
tfgrid-compose tfgrid-ai-agent create project  # Works

docs.title: select-project - Change Active Project
docs.text:
For apps that manage multiple projects (like tfgrid-ai-agent):

# Interactive selection
tfgrid-compose select-project

# Direct selection
tfgrid-compose select-project my-project

# Commands now use selected project
tfgrid-compose run       # Runs my-project
tfgrid-compose logs      # Logs for my-project

docs.title: unselect-project - Clear Project Selection
docs.text:
# Clear project context
tfgrid-compose unselect-project

# Commands require project name
tfgrid-compose run            # Error
tfgrid-compose run my-project # Works

docs.title: list - Show All Apps
docs.text:
See all deployed apps and which is active:

tfgrid-compose list

Output shows: - ✅ All deployed apps with IPs - ⭐ Current active context (marked with *) - 📊 Auto-context status (single app)

docs.title: Single App Scenario
docs.text:
# You deploy one app
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent

# NO switch needed!
tfgrid-compose create project
# → Automatically uses tfgrid-ai-agent

✅ Zero friction for common case

docs.title: Multiple Apps Scenario
docs.text:
# You have multiple apps
tfgrid-compose list
#   * tfgrid-ai-agent (active)
#     web-dashboard
#     api-backend

# Commands without context fail helpfully
tfgrid-compose create project
# → Error: Multiple apps. Use: tfgrid-compose select <app>

# Set context
tfgrid-compose select web-dashboard

# Now commands work
tfgrid-compose deploy

✅ Clear errors guide you

docs.title: Command Resolution Order
docs.text:
When you run a command, tfgrid-compose checks:

  1. Is it a generic command? (up, down, status, logs, ssh, etc.)

  2. If yes: Execute generic command

  3. Is it app-specific? (create, run, stop for ai-agent, etc.)

  4. Check context (auto or explicit)

  5. Route to app's command script

  6. Explicit app in command?

  7. tfgrid-compose tfgrid-ai-agent create overrides context

docs.title: Working with One App
docs.text:
# Deploy
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent

# Just use commands directly
tfgrid-compose create project
tfgrid-compose run project
tfgrid-compose projects

No select needed!

docs.title: Working with Multiple Apps
docs.text:
# Set context at start of work session
tfgrid-compose select tfgrid-ai-agent

# Work on multiple projects
tfgrid-compose create project1
tfgrid-compose create project2
tfgrid-compose run project1

# Select when changing apps
tfgrid-compose select web-dashboard
tfgrid-compose deploy

One select per work session

docs.title: Quick Commands Without Selection
docs.text:
# Explicit app name (no select needed)
tfgrid-compose tfgrid-ai-agent create quick-project
tfgrid-compose web-dashboard status

Override context for one-off commands

docs.title: Context Storage
docs.text:
• Location: ~/.config/tfgrid-compose/context.yaml
  • Format: YAML with app and project context
  • Scope: Global (all directories)

Example context file: 

active_app: tfgrid-ai-agent
active_project: my-project

docs.title: Auto-Detection Logic
docs.text:
1. Check deployed apps count
2. If count == 1:
   - Use that app automatically
   - No context file needed
3. If count > 1:
   - Check context file
   - If missing: Prompt to select
4. If count == 0:
   - Show help to deploy

docs.title: Example 1: Fresh Start
docs.text:
# Deploy your first app
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent

# Start using it immediately
tfgrid-compose create music-website
tfgrid-compose run music-website
tfgrid-compose monitor music-website

docs.title: Example 2: Multiple Apps
docs.text:
# Deploy apps
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent
tfgrid-compose up web-dashboard

# Set context
tfgrid-compose select tfgrid-ai-agent

# Work with AI agent
tfgrid-compose create backend-api
tfgrid-compose run backend-api

# Select other app
tfgrid-compose select web-dashboard
tfgrid-compose deploy

docs.title: Example 3: Mixed Mode
docs.text:
# Have context set to ai-agent
tfgrid-compose select tfgrid-ai-agent

# Use contextual commands
tfgrid-compose create project1

# Quick command on other app (no selection change)
tfgrid-compose web-dashboard status

# Continue with ai-agent (context unchanged)
tfgrid-compose run project1

docs.title: Node Selection & Filtering
docs.text:
Advanced node selection controls for precise deployment targeting on the ThreeFold Grid.

:::info Version Advanced node filtering is available in v0.14.0+ :::

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
TFGrid Compose provides multiple ways to control which nodes your deployments use:

  • Automatic Selection: Smart defaults based on resource requirements
  • Manual Selection: Specify exact node IDs
  • Persistent Preferences: ⭐ Set whitelist/blacklist once, apply to all deployments
  • Advanced Filtering: Health-based filtering and one-time CLI flags
  • Interactive Setup: Easy guided configuration with visual feedback

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
🚀 NEW: Persistent Preferences (Recommended)

Set your preferences once, use everywhere:

# Interactive setup (easiest)
tfgrid-compose whitelist

# Direct setup
tfgrid-compose whitelist nodes 920,891
tfgrid-compose blacklist nodes 617

# All deployments now auto-use your preferences
tfgrid-compose up myapp

Classic Method (Still Supported)

# Auto-select best node (default)
tfgrid-compose up myapp

# Use specific node
tfgrid-compose up myapp --node=574

# Filter by health
tfgrid-compose up myapp --max-cpu-usage=70 --min-uptime-days=30

# One-time blacklist (deprecated - use persistent preferences above)
tfgrid-compose up myapp --blacklist-node=617

docs.title: 1. Automatic Selection (Default)
docs.text:
TFGrid Compose automatically selects the best available node:

tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent

Selection Criteria: - ✅ Healthy nodes only - ✅ Non-dedicated nodes (available for rent) - ✅ Sufficient resources (CPU, RAM, disk) - ✅ Highest uptime (most stable)

docs.title: 2. Manual Node Selection
docs.text:
Specify exact node ID for precise control:

# Deploy to specific node
tfgrid-compose up myapp --node=574

# Verify node exists first
tfgrid-compose up myapp --node=574 --dry-run

docs.title: 3. Advanced Filtering
docs.text:
Combine multiple filters for precise targeting:

# Health-based filtering
tfgrid-compose up myapp --max-cpu-usage=70 --max-disk-usage=80

# Farm preferences
tfgrid-compose up myapp --whitelist-farm=Freefarm
tfgrid-compose up myapp --blacklist-farm=BadFarm

# Node exclusions
tfgrid-compose up myapp --blacklist-node=617,892

# Combined filters
tfgrid-compose up myapp \
  --whitelist-farm=Freefarm \
  --max-cpu-usage=70 \
  --min-uptime-days=30

docs.title: Global Configuration File
docs.text:
Set persistent preferences in ~/.config/tfgrid-compose/config.yaml:

# Node filtering (comma-separated lists)
blacklist_nodes: "617,892"
blacklist_farms: "BadFarm,ProblemFarm"
whitelist_farms: "Freefarm,TrustedFarm"

# Health thresholds (percentage usage)
max_cpu_usage: 70
max_disk_usage: 80

# Minimum uptime requirements (days)
min_uptime_days: 30

docs.title: Persistent Preferences System
docs.text:
Set your whitelist and blacklist preferences once, apply to all deployments!

The persistent preferences system allows you to configure node and farm filtering that automatically applies to all your deployments, eliminating the need to specify the same flags repeatedly.

# Interactive setup (recommended)
tfgrid-compose whitelist
# → Guided menu to set whitelist and blacklist preferences

# Set whitelist nodes
tfgrid-compose whitelist nodes 920,891

# Set whitelist farms
tfgrid-compose whitelist farms FastFarm,ReliableFarm

# Set blacklist nodes
tfgrid-compose blacklist nodes 615,888

# Set blacklist farms
tfgrid-compose blacklist farms SlowFarm,ProblematicFarm

# View current preferences
tfgrid-compose preferences --status

Benefits:

  • ✅ One-time setup - Configure once, use everywhere
  • ✅ Interactive mode - Easy guided configuration
  • ✅ Visual status - Clear view of current preferences
  • ✅ CLI overrides - Can still override for special cases
  • ✅ Team sharing - YAML config file is shareable

Configuration file: ~/.config/tfgrid-compose/preferences.yaml

docs.title: Legacy Configuration Commands
docs.text: The old config system is deprecated in favor of the new preference commands above:

docs.title: Configuration Commands
docs.text:
# Interactive configuration (recommended)
tfgrid-compose config
# → Shows menu to set/get values interactively

# Initialize configuration
tfgrid-compose config init

# View current settings
tfgrid-compose config show

# Set individual values
tfgrid-compose config set blacklist_nodes "617,892"
tfgrid-compose config set max_cpu_usage 70

# Get specific values
tfgrid-compose config get blacklist_nodes

docs.title: CLI Override Precedence
docs.text:
CLI flags override configuration file settings:

# Config file has max_cpu_usage: 70
# CLI flag overrides it
tfgrid-compose up myapp --max-cpu-usage=50

docs.title: Node Blacklisting
docs.text: Exclude specific nodes that have issues:

docs.title: Setting Up Persistent Preferences
docs.text:
Step 1: Interactive Setup (Recommended)

The easiest way to set up your preferences:

tfgrid-compose whitelist

This opens an interactive menu where you can: 1. Add whitelist nodes 2. Add whitelist farms 3. Add blacklist nodes 4. Add blacklist farms 5. Set deployment preferences (CPU, disk, uptime) 6. View current preferences 7. Clear preferences 8. Save and exit

Step 2: Direct Commands

Or use direct commands for quick setup:

# Whitelist preferred nodes and farms
tfgrid-compose whitelist nodes 920,891
tfgrid-compose whitelist farms FastFarm,ReliableFarm

# Blacklist problematic nodes and farms
tfgrid-compose blacklist nodes 615,888
tfgrid-compose blacklist farms SlowFarm,ProblematicFarm

# Set deployment preferences
tfgrid-compose whitelist  # Interactive mode for preferences

Step 3: View Current Settings

# View all preferences
tfgrid-compose preferences --status

# Shows:
# ✅ Whitelist (preferred nodes/farms):
#    Nodes: 920, 891
#    Farms: FastFarm, ReliableFarm
# ❌ Blacklist (avoided nodes/farms):
#    Nodes: 615, 888
#    Farms: SlowFarm, ProblematicFarm
# ⚙️  Deployment Preferences:
#    Max CPU Usage: 80%
#    Max Disk Usage: 60%
#    Min Uptime: 3 days

docs.title: Using Persistent Preferences
docs.text:
Once configured, all deployments automatically use your preferences:

# These commands automatically apply your persistent preferences
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-stack
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-gitea
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent

# Each deployment shows:
# ✅ Applying whitelist: nodes=920,891 farms=FastFarm,ReliableFarm
# ✅ Applying blacklist: nodes=615 farms=SlowFarm

docs.title: Overriding Persistent Preferences
docs.text:
You can still override preferences for specific deployments:

# Use persistent whitelist but override with specific node
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-stack --node=920

# Override whitelist for this deployment only
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-stack --whitelist-node=920,891 --blacklist-node=615

# Override with different whitelist farm
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-stack --whitelist-farm=PremiumFarm

Precedence Order: 1. CLI flags (highest precedence) 2. Persistent preferences 3. Default behavior (lowest precedence)

docs.title: Managing Preferences
docs.text:
Clear specific preferences: 

tfgrid-compose whitelist --clear      # Clear all whitelist
tfgrid-compose blacklist --clear      # Clear all blacklist

Update preferences: 

# Add more nodes to whitelist
tfgrid-compose whitelist nodes 920,891,1234

# Update blacklist farms
tfgrid-compose blacklist farms SlowFarm,ProblematicFarm,BadFarm

Check what will be applied: 

tfgrid-compose preferences --status

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
Preferences are stored in YAML format at: ~/.config/tfgrid-compose/preferences.yaml

# TFGrid Compose Persistent Preferences
whitelist:
  nodes: [920, 891]
  farms: [FastFarm, ReliableFarm]

blacklist:
  nodes: [615, 888]
  farms: [SlowFarm, ProblematicFarm]

preferences:
  max_cpu_usage: 80
  max_disk_usage: 60
  min_uptime_days: 3

metadata:
  version: "1.0"
  last_updated: "2025-10-31T17:03:00Z"

Benefits of YAML format: - ✅ Human-readable - Easy to edit manually - ✅ Shareable - Team members can copy preference files - ✅ Version control - Track changes over time - ✅ Backup/restore - Simple file copy

docs.title: Common Use Cases
docs.text:
Development Environment: 

tfgrid-compose whitelist nodes 920,891  # Fast, reliable nodes
tfgrid-compose whitelist farms FastFarm # Preferred farm

Production Environment: 

# More restrictive preferences for production
tfgrid-compose blacklist nodes 615,888  # Avoid known problematic nodes
tfgrid-compose blacklist farms SlowFarm # Avoid slow farms
tfgrid-compose whitelist nodes 920,891,1234  # Only use proven nodes

Team Environment: 

# Share preferences file with team
cp ~/.config/tfgrid-compose/preferences.yaml team-preferences.yaml
# Team members copy to their ~/.config/tfgrid-compose/preferences.yaml

Cost Optimization: 

# Prefer cheaper farms
tfgrid-compose whitelist farms Freefarm,AffordableFarm

Performance Optimization: 

# Prefer high-performance nodes
tfgrid-compose whitelist nodes 920,891,1234  # Top-tier nodes
tfgrid-compose blacklist farms SlowFarm      # Avoid slow farms

docs.title: Filtering Options
docs.text:
# Single node
tfgrid-compose up myapp --blacklist-node=617

# Multiple nodes
tfgrid-compose up myapp --blacklist-node=617,892,1234

# Persistent config
tfgrid-compose config set blacklist_nodes "617,892"

docs.title: Farm Filtering
docs.text:
Control which farms to use or avoid:

# Prefer specific farms (whitelist)
tfgrid-compose up myapp --whitelist-farm=Freefarm
tfgrid-compose up myapp --whitelist-farm=Freefarm,DigitalOceanFarm

# Avoid problematic farms (blacklist)
tfgrid-compose up myapp --blacklist-farm=BadFarm

docs.title: Health-Based Filtering
docs.text:
Filter nodes by resource utilization and stability:

# CPU usage threshold (percentage)
tfgrid-compose up myapp --max-cpu-usage=70

# Disk usage threshold (percentage)
tfgrid-compose up myapp --max-disk-usage=80

# Minimum uptime requirement (days)
tfgrid-compose up myapp --min-uptime-days=30

Health metrics are calculated as: - CPU Usage: (used_resources.cru / total_resources.cru) * 100 - Disk Usage: (used_resources.sru / total_resources.sru) * 100 - Uptime: uptime_seconds / 86400 (days)

docs.title: High-Performance Workloads
docs.text:
For GPU workloads or performance-critical apps:

# Prefer farms known for good hardware
tfgrid-compose up gpu-app \
  --whitelist-farm=NVIDIAFarm,GoogleFarm \
  --max-cpu-usage=50 \
  --min-uptime-days=60

docs.title: Cost Optimization
docs.text:
For cost-sensitive deployments:

# Use less utilized nodes (lower competition)
tfgrid-compose up myapp \
  --max-cpu-usage=30 \
  --max-disk-usage=50

docs.title: Reliability First
docs.text:
For production deployments:

# Prioritize stable, long-running nodes
tfgrid-compose up production-app \
  --min-uptime-days=90 \
  --max-cpu-usage=60

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
When deployments fail on certain nodes:

# Blacklist problematic nodes
tfgrid-compose up myapp --blacklist-node=617,892

# Add to persistent config
tfgrid-compose config set blacklist_nodes "617,892"

docs.title: GridProxy API Integration
docs.text:
All filtering uses the GridProxy API (https://gridproxy.grid.tf):

{
  "nodeId": 574,
  "farmName": "Freefarm",
  "country": "Germany",
  "healthy": true,
  "dedicated": false,
  "uptime": 1328644,
  "used_resources": {
    "cru": 35,
    "sru": 1597727834112,
    "hru": 0,
    "mru": 95701535130
  },
  "total_resources": {
    "cru": 56,
    "sru": 2000409772032,
    "hru": 144001663500288,
    "mru": 202711719936
  }
}

docs.title: Filtering Logic
docs.text:
1. Resource Check: Basic CPU/RAM/disk availability
  2. Health Filter: healthy == true && dedicated == false
  3. Blacklist Filter: Exclude specified nodes/farms
  4. Whitelist Filter: Include only specified farms (if set)
  5. Health Thresholds: Apply usage percentage limits
  6. Uptime Filter: Minimum uptime requirement
  7. Scoring: Sort by uptime (highest first)

docs.title: Performance Considerations
docs.text:
• Filters are applied client-side after GridProxy query
  • Large result sets (size=50) ensure good selection
  • Configuration cached locally for fast access
  • API calls respect rate limits

docs.title: Example 1: Production Deployment
docs.text:
# Configure for production use
tfgrid-compose config set whitelist_farms "Freefarm,TrustedFarm"
tfgrid-compose config set max_cpu_usage 60
tfgrid-compose config set min_uptime_days 30

# Deploy with additional filters
tfgrid-compose up production-app \
  --blacklist-node=617 \
  --max-disk-usage=75

docs.title: Example 2: Development Environment
docs.text:
# Relaxed filters for dev
tfgrid-compose up dev-app \
  --max-cpu-usage=90 \
  --min-uptime-days=7

docs.title: Example 3: GPU Workload
docs.text:
# Target GPU-capable farms
tfgrid-compose up gpu-app \
  --whitelist-farm=NVIDIAFarm,AMDfarm \
  --max-cpu-usage=50

docs.title: No Nodes Match Filters
docs.text:
tfgrid-compose up myapp --max-cpu-usage=10
# Error: No nodes found after applying filters

Solutions: - Relax filter criteria - Remove restrictive filters - Check configuration: tfgrid-compose config show

docs.title: Configuration Not Working
docs.text:
# Check config file exists
ls ~/.config/tfgrid-compose/config.yaml

# Reinitialize if corrupted
tfgrid-compose config init

docs.title: Node Not Available
docs.text:
tfgrid-compose up myapp --node=99999
# Error: Node 99999 is not available

Solutions: - Use auto-selection: tfgrid-compose up myapp - Check node status on dashboard.grid.tf - Remove --node flag

docs.title: 1. Start Simple
docs.text:
Begin with automatic selection, add filters as needed:

# Start basic
tfgrid-compose up myapp

# Add filters incrementally
tfgrid-compose up myapp --max-cpu-usage=70
tfgrid-compose up myapp --whitelist-farm=Freefarm

docs.title: 2. Use Configuration for Common Settings
docs.text:
Set frequently used filters globally:

tfgrid-compose config set max_cpu_usage 70
tfgrid-compose config set min_uptime_days 30

docs.title: 3. Override for Special Cases
docs.text:
Use CLI flags to override config for specific deployments:

# Config has max_cpu_usage: 70
# Override for this deployment
tfgrid-compose up special-app --max-cpu-usage=30

docs.title: 4. Monitor and Adjust
docs.text:
Check deployment success rates and adjust filters:

# If deployments fail often, relax filters
tfgrid-compose config set max_cpu_usage 80

# If getting poor performance, tighten filters
tfgrid-compose config set min_uptime_days 60

docs.title: Registry Integration
docs.text:
The TFGrid Compose registry allows you to discover and deploy apps by name, without manually cloning repositories.

:::info Version Registry integration is available in v0.13.4 (current version) :::

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Search available apps
tfgrid-compose search

# Deploy an app by name
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent

# List deployed apps
tfgrid-compose list

# Switch between apps
tfgrid-compose switch tfgrid-ai-agent

docs.title: Browse All Apps
docs.text:
tfgrid-compose search

Output: 

Available apps:

tfgrid-ai-agent      AI coding assistant with Qwen integration
tfgrid-gitea         Self-hosted Git service with web interface

docs.title: Search by Name
docs.text:
tfgrid-compose search tfgrid-ai-agent

Output: 

tfgrid-ai-agent      AI coding assistant with Qwen integration

docs.title: Search by Keyword
docs.text:
tfgrid-compose search ai

Output: 

tfgrid-ai-agent      AI coding assistant with Qwen integration

docs.title: Deploy by Name
docs.text:
Instead of cloning repositories manually, deploy directly by name:

tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent

What happens: 1. ✅ Fetches app info from registry 2. ✅ Downloads app repository to cache 3. ✅ Deploys the app (4 CPU, 8GB RAM, 100GB disk VM) 4. ✅ Sets it as active context

docs.title: Deploy from Local Path
docs.text:
You can still deploy from local paths:

tfgrid-compose up ./my-custom-app

Both methods work identically - the CLI automatically detects whether you're providing a name or path.

docs.title: List Deployed Apps
docs.text:
See all your deployed apps:

tfgrid-compose list

Output: 

  * wordpress (active)
    ai-agent
    nextcloud

The asterisk (*) indicates the currently active app.

docs.title: Switch Active App
docs.text:
Change which app commands operate on:

tfgrid-compose switch ai-agent

After switching: - tfgrid-compose logs → shows ai-agent logs - tfgrid-compose status → shows ai-agent status - tfgrid-compose exec → runs commands on ai-agent

docs.title: Context-Aware Commands
docs.text:
Once you switch, all commands operate on the active app:

# Switch to AI agent
tfgrid-compose switch tfgrid-ai-agent

# These all operate on AI agent now
tfgrid-compose logs
tfgrid-compose status
tfgrid-compose create my-project

# Switch to Gitea
tfgrid-compose switch tfgrid-gitea

# Now these operate on Gitea
tfgrid-compose address
tfgrid-compose logs

docs.title: Deploy Multiple Apps
docs.text:
# Search for apps
tfgrid-compose search

# Deploy AI agent for development
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent

# Deploy Gitea for code storage
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-gitea

# List all deployed apps
tfgrid-compose list

Output: 

  * tfgrid-gitea (active)
    tfgrid-ai-agent

docs.title: Work with Different Apps
docs.text:
# Work with AI agent
tfgrid-compose switch tfgrid-ai-agent
tfgrid-compose create my-project
tfgrid-compose monitor my-project
tfgrid-compose logs

# Check Gitea status
tfgrid-compose switch tfgrid-gitea
tfgrid-compose address
tfgrid-compose logs

docs.title: App Caching
docs.text: Apps are automatically cached locally for fast deployment.

docs.title: Cache Location
docs.text:
~/.config/tfgrid-compose/
├── registry/
│   └── apps.yaml           # Registry cache (1hr TTL)
├── apps/
│   ├── wordpress/          # Cached app repos
│   ├── ai-agent/
│   └── nextcloud/
├── state/
│   ├── wordpress/          # Per-app deployment state
│   ├── ai-agent/
│   └── nextcloud/
└── current-app             # Active app pointer

docs.title: Cache Behavior
docs.text:
• Registry: Refreshed every hour automatically
  • Apps: Downloaded once, reused for all deployments
  • Updates: Apps use cached version (pull updates manually if needed)

docs.title: Updating Cached Apps
docs.text:
# Navigate to cached app
cd ~/.config/tfgrid-compose/apps/wordpress

# Pull latest changes
git pull

# Redeploy with updates
tfgrid-compose up wordpress

docs.title: State Management
docs.text: Each app has isolated state, preventing conflicts.

docs.title: Per-App State
docs.text:
# Deploy two apps
tfgrid-compose up wordpress
tfgrid-compose up nextcloud

# Each has independent state
~/.config/tfgrid-compose/state/
├── wordpress/
│   ├── vm_ip
│   ├── wireguard.conf
│   └── ansible_inventory.yaml
└── nextcloud/
    ├── vm_ip
    ├── wireguard.conf
    └── ansible_inventory.yaml

docs.title: No Conflicts
docs.text: You can deploy the same app multiple times by deploying from different paths with different names.

docs.title: Old Way (Pre-v0.10.0)
docs.text:
# Manual steps
git clone https://github.com/tfgrid-studio/wordpress-app
cd wordpress-app
tfgrid-compose up .

docs.title: New Way (v0.10.0+)
docs.text:
# One command
tfgrid-compose up wordpress

docs.title: Registry Format
docs.text: The registry is a simple YAML file hosted on GitHub.

docs.title: Example Registry Entry
docs.text:
tfgrid-ai-agent:
  description: AI coding assistant with Qwen integration
  repo: https://github.com/tfgrid-studio/tfgrid-ai-agent
  pattern: single-vm
  version: v0.3.0
  tags:
    - ai
    - coding
    - development
    - qwen
  requirements:
    cpu: 4
    memory: 8GB
    disk: 100GB

tfgrid-gitea:
  description: Self-hosted Git service with web interface
  repo: https://github.com/tfgrid-studio/tfgrid-gitea
  pattern: single-vm
  version: v1.0.0
  tags:
    - git
    - scm
    - repository
    - collaboration
  requirements:
    cpu: 2
    memory: 4GB
    disk: 50GB

docs.title: Registry Location
docs.text: Public registry: https://github.com/tfgrid-studio/registry

docs.title: Mix Registry and Local Apps
docs.text:
# Deploy from registry
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent

# Deploy from local path
tfgrid-compose up ./my-custom-app

# Both work together
tfgrid-compose list

Output: 

  * my-custom-app (active)
    tfgrid-ai-agent

docs.title: Deploy Same App Multiple Times
docs.text:
# Deploy production AI agent from registry
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent

# Deploy staging AI agent from local fork
tfgrid-compose up ./ai-agent-staging

docs.title: App Not Found
docs.text:
tfgrid-compose up myapp
# Error: App 'myapp' not found in registry

Solution: Search the registry to find the correct name:

tfgrid-compose search

docs.title: Cache Issues
docs.text:
If the registry seems outdated, it refreshes automatically after 1 hour. To force refresh:

# Remove cache
rm -rf ~/.config/tfgrid-compose/registry/

# Next command will fetch fresh registry
tfgrid-compose search

docs.title: App Already Deployed
docs.text:
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent
# Error: App 'tfgrid-ai-agent' is already deployed

Solution: Destroy first or switch to it:

# Option 1: Destroy and redeploy
tfgrid-compose down tfgrid-ai-agent
tfgrid-compose up tfgrid-ai-agent

# Option 2: Switch to it
tfgrid-compose switch tfgrid-ai-agent

docs.title: 1. Search Before Deploying
docs.text:
Always search to find the right app name:

tfgrid-compose search

docs.title: 2. List Regularly
docs.text:
Keep track of deployed apps:

tfgrid-compose list

docs.title: 3. Switch Explicitly
docs.text:
Always switch before running commands:

tfgrid-compose switch myapp
tfgrid-compose logs

docs.title: 4. Clean Up Unused Apps
docs.text:
Destroy apps you're no longer using:

tfgrid-compose down tfgrid-ai-agent

docs.title: Code of Conduct
docs.text: Version: 1.0 Last Updated: October 14, 2025 Applies To: All TFGrid Studio projects and community spaces

docs.title: Our Pledge
docs.text:
We as members, contributors, and leaders pledge to make participation in TFGrid Studio a harassment-free experience for everyone, regardless of age, body size, visible or invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity and expression, level of experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, or sexual identity and orientation.

We pledge to act and interact in ways that contribute to an open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, and healthy community.

docs.title: ✅ Expected Behavior
docs.text:
Examples of behavior that contributes to a positive environment:

  • Respect: Treating all community members with respect and consideration
  • Kindness: Being welcoming and supportive to newcomers
  • Constructive Feedback: Providing helpful, actionable criticism
  • Collaboration: Working together toward common goals
  • Responsibility: Taking accountability for mistakes and learning from them
  • Focus: Keeping discussions relevant and productive
  • Empathy: Showing understanding of different viewpoints and experiences
  • Professionalism: Maintaining professional standards in all interactions

docs.title: ❌ Unacceptable Behavior
docs.text:
Examples of unacceptable behavior include:

  • Harassment: Trolling, insulting/derogatory comments, personal or political attacks
  • Discrimination: Any form of discrimination or exclusionary jokes/language
  • Privacy Violation: Publishing others' private information without permission
  • Intimidation: Threatening, stalking, or doxxing community members
  • Sexual Content: Unwelcome sexual attention or advances
  • Disruption: Deliberately disrupting discussions or community activities
  • Spam: Excessive self-promotion or off-topic posts
  • Bad Faith: Arguing in bad faith or sea-lioning
  • Weaponization: Using the Code of Conduct as a tool for harassment

docs.title: Scope
docs.text:
This Code of Conduct applies to all TFGrid Studio spaces, including but not limited to:

Online Spaces:

  • GitHub repositories (issues, pull requests, discussions)
  • Official Discord/Slack channels
  • Social media accounts
  • Email communications
  • Documentation sites
  • Video calls and meetings

Offline Spaces:

  • Conferences and meetups
  • Workshops and training sessions
  • Any event representing TFGrid Studio

This Code of Conduct also applies when an individual is officially representing the community in public spaces.

docs.title: Reporting
docs.text:
If you experience or witness unacceptable behavior, or have any other concerns, please report it by:

  1. Email: contact@tfgrid.studio
  2. GitHub: Create a confidential security advisory
  3. Direct Message: Contact a maintainer privately

What to include in your report:

  • Your contact information
  • Names (usernames) of people involved
  • Description of the behavior
  • Links or screenshots (if applicable)
  • Any other relevant context
  • Whether you prefer to remain anonymous

All reports will be kept confidential. We will never share reporter information without explicit consent unless required by law.

docs.title: Response Timeline
docs.text:
• Acknowledgment: Within 24 hours
  • Initial Review: Within 3 business days
  • Resolution: Varies by complexity, typically within 1-2 weeks

You will receive updates on the progress of your report.

docs.title: Enforcement Actions
docs.text:
Project maintainers are responsible for clarifying and enforcing our standards. They will take appropriate and fair corrective action in response to any behavior that they deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, or harmful.

Possible consequences include:

docs.title: 1. Warning
docs.text:
Impact: A private, written warning explaining the violation and why the behavior was inappropriate.

Duration: Single incident

docs.title: 2. Temporary Ban
docs.text:
Impact: A temporary ban from all community spaces (GitHub, Discord, etc.)

Duration: Days to weeks, depending on severity

docs.title: 3. Permanent Ban
docs.text:
Impact: Permanent ban from all TFGrid Studio community spaces

Duration: Indefinite

docs.title: Appeal Process
docs.text:
If you believe an enforcement action was made in error, you may appeal by:

  1. Emailing contact@tfgrid.studio with "Appeal" in the subject
  2. Providing new information or context
  3. Explaining why you believe the decision was incorrect

Appeals will be reviewed by a different maintainer when possible.

docs.title: GitHub
docs.text:
Issues and Pull Requests:

  • Stay on topic
  • Be patient with maintainers (they're volunteers)
  • Don't demand immediate responses
  • Provide complete information (logs, versions, steps to reproduce)
  • Close resolved issues

Code Reviews:

  • Focus on code, not people ("This function could be improved" vs "You wrote bad code")
  • Suggest alternatives
  • Acknowledge good work
  • Accept feedback gracefully

Discussions:

  • Search before posting duplicates
  • Use appropriate categories
  • Mark solutions when found
  • Help others when you can

docs.title: Chat (Discord/Slack)
docs.text:
• Keep conversations in appropriate channels
  • No excessive @mentions
  • Use threads for long discussions
  • Respect Do Not Disturb status
  • No spam or unsolicited DMs
  • Keep memes and off-topic content minimal

docs.title: Social Media
docs.text:
• Don't speak on behalf of TFGrid Studio without authorization
  • Be respectful in comments and replies
  • Disclose your relationship when promoting TFGrid Studio projects
  • Don't engage with trolls or bad-faith actors

docs.title: Maintainer Responsibilities
docs.text:
Project maintainers are responsible for:

  • Modeling: Exemplifying the Code of Conduct in their own behavior
  • Enforcing: Fairly and consistently enforcing the Code of Conduct
  • Communicating: Clearly communicating expectations and decisions
  • Transparency: Being transparent about enforcement actions (while respecting privacy)
  • Improvement: Continuously improving community health

Maintainers who do not follow or enforce the Code of Conduct in good faith may face temporary or permanent repercussions as determined by other members of the project's leadership.

docs.title: Attribution
docs.text:
This Code of Conduct is adapted from:

  • Contributor Covenant, version 2.1
  • Django Code of Conduct
  • Rust Code of Conduct

docs.title: Changes
docs.text:
We may update this Code of Conduct from time to time. All changes will be announced through official channels and posted to this document.

Version History:

  • v1.0 (2025-10-14): Initial Code of Conduct

docs.text: Enforcement Team: contact@tfgrid.studio General Inquiries: contact@tfgrid.studio Security Issues: See Security Policy

docs.title: Contributing to TFGrid Studio
docs.text: Welcome! We're excited that you're interested in contributing to TFGrid Studio. This guide will help you get started.

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text:
1. Getting Started
  2. How to Contribute
  3. Development Workflow
  4. Code Standards
  5. Testing
  6. Documentation
  7. Community

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
For tfgrid-compose development:

  • Bash 4.0+
  • Git
  • OpenTofu or Terraform
  • Ansible
  • Basic understanding of shell scripting

For documentation:

  • Markdown knowledge
  • Git
  • Python 3.8+ (for local MkDocs preview)

docs.title: Set Up Development Environment
docs.text:
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/tfgrid-studio/tfgrid-compose
cd tfgrid-compose

# Install prerequisites
# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt update
sudo apt install ansible git

# Install OpenTofu (recommended)
curl -L https://get.opentofu.org/install-opentofu.sh | sudo bash

# Test your setup
./cli/tfgrid-compose --version

docs.title: First Time Setup
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository on GitHub
  2. Clone your fork: 
    git clone https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/tfgrid-compose
cd tfgrid-compose
  3. Add upstream remote: 
    git remote add upstream https://github.com/tfgrid-studio/tfgrid-compose
  4. Create a branch: 
    git checkout -b feature/my-feature

docs.title: Types of Contributions
docs.text: We welcome many types of contributions:

docs.title: 🐛 Bug Reports
docs.text:
Found a bug? Help us fix it!

Before reporting:

  • Search existing issues
  • Try latest version
  • Gather reproduction steps

Create an issue with:

  • Clear title
  • Description of the bug
  • Steps to reproduce
  • Expected vs actual behavior
  • Environment details (OS, versions)
  • Logs (with sensitive data removed)

docs.title: 💡 Feature Requests
docs.text:
Have an idea for improvement?

Create an issue with:

  • Clear use case
  • Proposed solution
  • Alternatives considered
  • Willingness to implement

docs.title: 📝 Documentation
docs.text:
Improve or add documentation:

  • Fix typos
  • Clarify confusing sections
  • Add examples
  • Write guides
  • Translate content

docs.title: 💻 Code Contributions
docs.text:
Implement features or fix bugs:

  • Bug fixes
  • New features
  • Performance improvements
  • Refactoring
  • Tests

docs.title: 🎨 Design Patterns
docs.text:
Create new deployment patterns:

  • Follow Pattern Contract
  • Document use cases
  • Provide examples
  • Test thoroughly

docs.title: 1. Pick an Issue
docs.text:
Good first issues:

  • Look for good-first-issue label
  • Check help-wanted label
  • Simple bug fixes
  • Documentation improvements

Claim an issue:

  • Comment "I'd like to work on this"
  • Wait for assignment (prevents duplicates)

docs.title: 2. Create a Branch
docs.text:
# Get latest code
git checkout main
git pull upstream main

# Create feature branch
git checkout -b type/description

# Branch naming:
# feature/add-monitoring
# fix/ssh-timeout
# docs/architecture-guide
# refactor/validation-module

docs.title: 3. Make Changes
docs.text:
Best practices:

  • Make focused, atomic commits
  • Write clear commit messages
  • Test your changes
  • Update documentation
  • Follow code standards

docs.title: 4. Commit Your Changes
docs.text:
Commit message format: 

type(scope): brief description

Detailed explanation (if needed)

Fixes #123

Types:

  • feat: New feature
  • fix: Bug fix
  • docs: Documentation only
  • refactor: Code refactoring
  • test: Adding tests
  • chore: Maintenance tasks

Examples: 

git commit -m "feat(orchestrator): add multi-deployment support"
git commit -m "fix(validation): resolve mnemonic loading issue"
git commit -m "docs(architecture): add system diagrams"

docs.title: 5. Push and Create Pull Request
docs.text:
# Push to your fork
git push origin feature/my-feature

# Create PR on GitHub
# - Fill out the PR template
# - Link related issues
# - Request review

docs.title: 6. Code Review Process
docs.text:
What to expect: - Maintainers will review within 3-5 business days - You may be asked to make changes - CI tests must pass - At least one approval required

Responding to feedback: - Be receptive to suggestions - Ask questions if unclear - Make requested changes - Push updates to your branch - Re-request review when ready

docs.title: 7. Merge
docs.text: Once approved: - Maintainer will merge your PR - Branch will be deleted automatically - Changes go into next release

docs.title: Shell Scripts (Bash)
docs.text:
Style: 

#!/usr/bin/env bash
# Brief description of script purpose

set -e  # Exit on error

# Constants in UPPERCASE
SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"

# Functions use snake_case
my_function() {
    local param=$1

    # Clear logic with comments
    echo "Processing: $param"
}

# Call functions
my_function "value"

Best practices: - Use set -e for error handling - Quote variables: "$var" not $var - Use local for function variables - Add comments for complex logic - Use meaningful variable names - Check command existence: command -v cmd

docs.title: Terraform/OpenTofu
docs.text:
Style: 

# Use consistent formatting
resource "grid_deployment" "vm" {
  name = "my_deployment"

  # Group related attributes
  network {
    node_id = var.node_id
    name    = "network"
  }
}

# Document outputs
output "primary_ip" {
  description = "Primary IP address for SSH connection"
  value       = local.primary_ip
}

Requirements: - Implement pattern contract - Use variables for configurability - Document all outputs - Run terraform fmt before committing

docs.title: Ansible
docs.text:
Style: 

---
# Use descriptive task names
- name: Install required packages
  apt:
    name:
      - git
      - curl
      - build-essential
    state: present
    update_cache: yes
  become: yes

# Use handlers for services
- name: Configure application
  template:
    src: app.conf.j2
    dest: /etc/app/config.conf
  notify: restart application

handlers:
  - name: restart application
    systemd:
      name: app
      state: restarted

Best practices: - Use descriptive task names - Idempotent operations - Use handlers for restarts - Tag tasks appropriately - Test playbooks thoroughly

docs.title: Manual Testing
docs.text:
Before submitting PR: 1. Test your changes locally 2. Try different configurations 3. Test error cases 4. Verify logs are helpful

Test script: 

# Example test workflow
cd tfgrid-compose

# Test validation
./cli/tfgrid-compose up /nonexistent/path  # Should fail gracefully

# Test deployment (if you have access to ThreeFold Grid)
./cli/tfgrid-compose up ../tfgrid-ai-agent

# Test cleanup
./cli/tfgrid-compose down ../tfgrid-ai-agent

docs.title: Automated Testing
docs.text:
Run test suite: 

# Run validation tests
./tests/test-validation.sh

# Add new tests for your changes
# tests/test-my-feature.sh

docs.title: Test Checklist
docs.text:
• Code follows style guide
  • Manual testing completed
  • Error cases handled
  • Logs are clear and helpful
  • Documentation updated
  • No sensitive data in commits

docs.title: When to Update Docs
docs.text: Always update docs when: - Adding new features - Changing behavior - Adding CLI commands - Modifying configuration options - Fixing bugs that affect usage

docs.title: Documentation Structure
docs.text:
tfgrid-docs/ (public-facing): - User guides - API documentation - Tutorials - Troubleshooting

tfgrid-compose/README.md: - Project overview - Quick start - Links to full docs

docs.title: Writing Style
docs.text:
Be clear and concise: - Short sentences - Active voice - Clear examples - Step-by-step instructions

Good example: 

## Deploy Application

Deploy your application to ThreeFold Grid:

```bash
tfgrid-compose up /path/to/app

This command will: 1. Validate prerequisites 2. Create infrastructure 3. Configure networking 4. Deploy your application 

**Bad example:**
```markdown
## Deployment

You can deploy stuff with the up command maybe.

All contributors must follow our Code of Conduct.

Key points: - Be respectful - Be inclusive - Be constructive - Be professional

docs.title: Communication Channels
docs.text:
GitHub: - Issues: Bug reports, feature requests - Discussions: Questions, ideas, help - Pull Requests: Code contributions
